description: Luxemburg is declaring a state of crisis on 17 March, which gives the Government the possibility to set up emergency measures in order to face the crisis. Thus, a regulatory and legal framework is established, in line with the Luxembourg Constitution: the scope covered by this Article is limited to measures which cannot be taken in good time through the normal legislative procedure. The Chamber of Deputies can, at every moment, suspend or revoke the state of crisis: Parliamentary control is this fully guaranteed.

Luxemburg banned third-country nationals to enter the territory of the Grand Duchy. The restriction was put in place, initially, for a one month period starting on March 18, 2020.  There are several exemptions from this ban, including for  Belgian, French, and German cross-border workers.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
compliance: Mandatory with Exceptions (Please list exceptions in the text entry)

description: Luxemburg announces that from 24 March onwards the RGTR bus lines 158 Kirchberg - Remich - Merzig (D) and 159 Luxembourg - Losheim (D) will be diverted via Schengen, then Besch, to Nennig. From then on the routes remain unchanged. Nennig Zoll is replaced by Nennig Bahnhof.

target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: Luxemburg is recommending risk groups to reduce social interaction, travel and avoiding mass gatherings and hospital visits.
type_text: The Luxemburg government has issued official recommendations for risk groups to avoid travel, social gatherings, shopping at rush hours and public transport.

description: Luxemburg is recommending a visitors ban on care homes to all relatives and friends of residents of elderly homes.
type_text: Luxemburg recommended to implement a visitors ban in all elderly homes.

description: Luxembourg: Covid-19: Introduction of family support leave
type_text: As part of the government's measures to limit the spread of coronavirus, paid leave was introduced to support the family. This leave is intended to help private sector workers and self-employed persons who are forced to stop working due to the closure of an institution for people with a disability or for elderly people, so that they can care for an adult with a disability or for an elderly person living in their household.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: Luxembourg: COVID-19: New procedure for applying for short-time work in cases of force majeure due to the COVID-19 crisis announced on March 27.
type_text: In order to preserve jobs and thus prevent redundancies, Luxembourg labour law provides for various regulations on short-time working. Short-time work enables companies to keep well-trained and experienced employees in employment even in times of crisis.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: Luxemburg announced the reopening of visits to care and health homes in Luxembourg in a 28th April press conference. However, the respect of hygiene rules remains essential with numerous rules to keep the social distance.
type_text: Reopening families to go back visiting people in care homes
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
Luxemburg, through its Minister for Family and Integration, announced the reopening of visits to care and health homes to families on a Tuesday 28th April press conference. The timing of the openings depends on care homes' managers.
